## 1. Theoretical mechanisms – why people think death‑penalty deterrence could differ from LWOP

| Mechanism | How it is supposed to work for the death penalty | How it is supposed to work for life imprisonment | Key assumptions |
|-----------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|-----------------|
| **Severity (punishment‐aversion)** | The ultimate loss of life is assumed to be more frightening than any length of incarceration, so rational offenders will avoid crimes that could lead to execution. | LWOP is severe but still allows the offender to “live”; the threat is less extreme. | Offenders are rational calculators of personal cost. |
| **Irreversibility / “no second chances”** | Execution eliminates any possibility of release, parole, or escape, which some argue makes the sanction more credible. | Life sentences can be reduced, pardoned, or may be subject to compassionate release, potentially weakening the perceived finality. | Offenders are aware of the legal system’s ability to modify sentences. |
| **Celerity (speed of punishment)** | If executions are carried out quickly after conviction, the temporal proximity could increase deterrence (the “swift‑justice” effect). | LWOP often involves long appeals and may take years before the sentence is finally imposed, possibly diluting deterrent impact. | The criminal justice system can deliver a rapid, certain outcome. |
| **Publicity / “general deterrence”** | Highly publicized executions are thought to send a strong societal signal that certain crimes will be met with death, amplifying the deterrent message. | Life sentences receive less media attention; the “message” may be weaker. | Media coverage reliably reaches potential offenders and influences their cost‑benefit calculations. |
| **Specific deterrence (preventing the same person from re‑offending)** | Execution removes the offender permanently, guaranteeing they cannot commit another crime. | LWOP also removes the offender from society, but only as long as the sentence is upheld; escape, parole, or early release are theoretically possible. | The primary goal is preventing future offenses by the same individual. |
| **Moral or symbolic signaling** | Some argue that the death penalty expresses a societal condemnation that “matches” the moral gravity of murder, reinforcing a norm against killing. | Life imprisonment may be seen as a “soft” response that fails to convey the same moral weight. | Offenders internalize societal norms and are influenced by the symbolic meaning of punishments. |

**Take‑away:** The death penalty is theorized to be a stronger deterrent *because* it is (a) more severe, (b) irreversible, (c) potentially swifter, and (d) more visible in the public sphere. All of those factors rely on the assumption that potential offenders are rational, well‑informed, and responsive to the “cost” of punishment.
